intro: Mansoa onohualcoides, commonly known as the Peruvian moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its large, showy white flowers that open at night, emitting a strong, sweet fragrance. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are woody and somewhat succulent. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in cloud forests.
